document.heading: Early Childhood Educator Pay Scales Emergency Amendment Act of 2025

To amend, on an emergency basis, the Day Care Policy Act of 1979 to update the minimum salaries child development facilities must pay assistant and lead teachers beginning in January 2026 to participate in the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Program and to incorporate the Early Childhood Educator Equitable Compensation Task Force and the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Fund into the act; and to make conforming amendments.
document.text: BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Early Childhood Educator Pay Scales Emergency Amendment Act of 2025".

section.text: The Day Care Policy Act of 1979, effective September 19, 1979 (D.C. Law 3-16; D.C. Official Code § 4-401 et seq.), is amended as follows:

The term "community-based organization" means a Head Start or early childhood education program operated by a nonprofit entity, faith-based organization, or other entity that participates in federally funded early childhood programs.

para.text: Subsection (c) is amended as follows:
Paragraph (1) is amended to read as follows:

Beginning February 1, 2026, and annually by February 1 thereafter, the Department shall provide a public report to the Council and to the members of the Early Childhood Educator Equitable Compensation Task Force that analyzes possible updates to the minimum salaries for assistant and lead teachers for the following fiscal year. The analysis shall consider the salary tables provided in subsection (b-1) of this section from the past 3 years. The report shall include:

Recommended minimum salaries for the upcoming fiscal year, adjusted to reflect the year-over-year percentage change in the Chained Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers for the Washington-Baltimore, DC-MD-VA-WV area;

A comparison of the District's current minimum salaries with those in surrounding jurisdictions, including educators in pre-kindergarten and kindergarten classrooms, and recommendations for keeping District salaries competitive across the region;
A comparison of the District's current minimum salaries with those for comparable positions under the current operative contract with the Washington Teachers' Union;

An assessment of the projected funding needed for the upcoming fiscal year to make full payments to all child development facilities with existing agreements with the Department to implement the ECE salary scale based on the current and recommended salaries; and

A discussion of the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Program's impacts and outcomes, and recommendations, if any, for improving the program's impact, funding formula, or administrative operations to enhance outcomes and cost efficacy.
Paragraph (3) is repealed.

The Chief Financial Officer shall report to the Council on a quarterly basis indicating the fiscal year expenditures from the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Fund ("Fund") to date and the total amount of funds remaining in the Fund. The report shall be submitted no later than 21 days following the end of each quarter.

para.text: Section 11d (D.C. Official Code § 4-410.04) is revived and amended to read as follows:

section.heading: Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Fund.

para.text: There is established as a special fund the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Fund ("Fund"), which shall be a continuation of the fund established by the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Fund Establishment Act of 2021, effective November 13, 2021 (D.C. Law 24-45; D.C. Official Code § 1-325.431), and administered by the Department in accordance with subsection (c) of this section.
The following funds shall be deposited into the Fund:
In Fiscal Year 2022, $53,920,878 in local funds;
In Fiscal Year 2023, $72,889,092 in local funds;
In Fiscal Year 2024, $69,508,332 in local funds;
In Fiscal Year 2025, $70,000,000 in local funds; and
In Fiscal Year 2026, $72,126,902 in local funds.
The Fund shall be used to:
Support the implementation of the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Program;

Subject to appropriations, reduce health insurance premiums paid by child development facilities, or employees of child development facilities eligible to receive the minimum salaries listed in section 11b, pursuant to an agreement with the District of Columbia Health Benefit Exchange; and
Pay the Department administrative costs related to implementing the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Program, which may include:
Personnel and associated non-personnel costs;
Grantee or contractor costs related to distributing Fund monies; and
Costs related to providing technical assistance to child development facilities.
Administrative costs authorized to be paid pursuant to subparagraph (A) of this paragraph shall not exceed 5% of the annual amount deposited in the Fund.

Money deposited into the Fund but not expended in a fiscal year shall not revert to the unassigned fund balance of the General Fund of the District of Columbia at the end of a fiscal year, or at any time.
Subject to authorization in an approved budget and financial plan, any funds appropriated in the Fund shall be continually available without regard to fiscal year limitation.
Unless otherwise prohibited by federal law, lump-sum payments an individual receives from the Fund shall not be counted as income or assets:

For the purposes of determining eligibility or calculating benefits under the District of Columbia Public Assistance Act of 1982, effective April 6, 1982 (D.C. Law 4-101; D.C. Official Code § 4-201.01 et seq.); and
For the purpose of determining eligibility or calculating benefits for the following benefit programs:

D.C. HealthCare Alliance, referenced in section 8(2) of the Department of Health Care Finance Establishment Act of 2007, effective February 27, 2008 (D.C. Law 17-109; D.C. Official Code § 7-771.07(2)), or any subsequent program established to provide public health insurance coverage to residents ineligible for Medicaid;
Educational scholarships the District administers with local funds;
Home Purchase Assistance Program, referenced in section 3a of the Home Purchase Assistance Fund Act of 1978, effective July 1, 2016 (D.C. Law 21-139; D.C. Official Code § 42-2602.01);

Housing subsidy vouchers issued through the Rent Supplement Program, established by section 26a of the District of Columbia Housing Authority Act of 1999, effective March 2, 2007 (D.C. Law 16-192; D.C. Official Code § 6-226);

Grandparent Caregiver Program established by section 102 of the Grandparent Caregivers Pilot Program Establishment Act of 2005, effective March 8, 2006 (D.C. Law 16-69; D.C. Official Code § 4-251.02);

Close Relative Caregiver Program, established by section 102 of the Close Relative Caregiver Subsidy Pilot Program Establishment Amendment Act of 2019, effective November 26, 2019 (D.C. Law 23-32; D.C. Official Code § 4-251.22); and
Other District government benefit programs administered with local funds, including Strong Families, Strong Futures.

para.text: A new section 15c is added to read as follows:

section.heading: Early Childhood Educator Equitable Compensation Task Force.

para.text: There is established by the Council an Early Childhood Educator Equitable Compensation Task Force ("Task Force"), which shall have, as of the effective date of the Early Childhood Educator Pay Scales Emergency Amendment Act of 2025, passed on emergency basis on October 21, 2025 (Enrolled version of Bill 26-433) ("ECE Pay Scales Amendment Act"), the same members as the Early Childhood Educator Equitable Compensation Task Force established pursuant to the Early Childhood Educator Equitable Compensation Task Force Act of 2021, effective November 13, 2021 (D.C. Law 24-45, D.C. Official Code § 38-2241 et seq.), until their successors are appointed.

The Task Force shall be composed of the Chairman of the Council, or his or her designee, the State Superintendent of Education, or his or her designee, and 12 District residents, appointed by the Chairman, representing the following entities or groups:
Families whose children are receiving or have received early childhood education or childcare services from early childhood development facilities in the District;
Community-based organizations;
Early childhood education associations, advocacy or research organizations;
Operators of child development facilities who participate in the childcare subsidy programs;
Operators of child development facilities who do not currently participate in the childcare subsidy program;
Operators of home-based child development facilities;
Employees of child development facilities; and
An individual with an expertise in economics or policy, who has an understanding of the District's early childhood development and education sector.
At least 2 members of the Task Force shall be employees of child development facilities, one of whom shall be a participant in the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Program.
The Chairman, or his or her designee, shall serve as the Chairperson of the Task Force.
Following the effective date of the ECE Pay Scales Amendment Act, the Task Force shall convene:
At least every 3rd calendar year starting in 2027; or
When deemed necessary by the Chairman of the Council.
Within 60 days after the Department publishes the report required pursuant to section 11b(c), the Task Force shall meet and submit a response to the Council that:
Reviews the Department's report, the recommended salary scales, the Early Childhood Educator Pay Equity Program funding formula, and the state of the early childhood education workforce; and
Makes recommendations to improve systemic supports.

Should a vacancy occur on the Task Force after the effective date of the ECE Pay Scales Amendment Act, the Chairman, in consultation with the State Superintendent of Education, shall appoint an individual to fill the vacancy whose qualifications and experience are comparable to those of the individual who vacated the role, and whose appointment maintains the composition requirements set forth in subsection (b) of this section.
